reviewText: This is a nice, very G-rated family movie, particularly for those who enjoy a western setting and lots of horses. Loosely based on Mel Tillis' teen novel, "The Wild Horse Killers", it tells the story of Hank (a late teens Linda Blair, in one of her better roles), an college girl home for the summer at her father's ranch. When she sees wild mustangs being rounded up for the purpose of being killed and turned into dog food, she decides to singlehandedly herd the mustangs 150 miles away to a protected federal park.The film changes the pivotal character of a friendly old prospector, who helps Hank achieve her goals, to a young and handsome cowboy, Charlie (Michael Wincott, unrecognizable as a baby-faced teenager) to add a note of romance to the story. In a nicely done feminist turn, Charlie admires Hank more than lusts for her, and follows her exploits with the goal of helping her achieve her goals and thereby win her respect. (It would be nice if a few adult films ever pursued such a thoughtful potential romantic subpot.)There is plenty of nice scenery and Ms. Blair is an accomplished horsewoman, who looks extremely comfortable and natural in this part. I don't think anyone would call her a great actress, but this role fits her in a  down-to-earth way that I don't think any of her other parts over the years have. The late Richard Crenna has a small role as her supportive dad.This film is long out-of-print -- it's over 25 years old -- and I think that's a shame. There are not a lot of really good family films of the non-animated, non-slapstick comedy kind...and not a great deal of good horse/western type of films in the first place. I think this compares very favorably to "Return of the Black Stallion", with the added plus of a strong and competent female heroine.If you get a chance to rent or view this with your family, go for it. I think it would be especially appreciated by horse-loving adolescent girls.
summary: Pleasant family movie for horse lovers

reviewText: This is Linda Blair at her best. I have this movie in VHS, but we don't have a VHS player anymore. I couldn't part with it! LOL! I kept searching for it on DVD and I found it! I was so excited!Some of the parts I didn't remember...but it made new memories for me!Cheryl

reviewText: A REAL GOOD FAMILY MOVIE. LINDA TRIES TO SAVE WILD MUSTANGS FROM THE DOG FOOD COMPANIES.  SHE GOES TO BRING THEM TO FEDERAL LAND FOR SAFETY ALL BY HERSELF. SHE IS A VERY GOOD HORSEWOMAN, AND THE FILM SHOWS IT. THERE IS A LOVE INTEREST WITH CHARLIE WHO TRIES TO HELP HER GET CLEAN WATER FOR THE HORSES. RICHARD CRENNA PLAY HER FATHER WHO DOESN'T AGREE WITH HER GOING TO FEDERAL LAND WITH THE HORSES. BUT SHE GETS THEM THERE TO SAFETY. AL WAXMAN PLAYS THE ONE WHO WANTS TO SELL THE HORSES FOR FOOD. THE SCENERY IS BEAUTIFUL FILMED IN CANADA AND NEVADA. IF YOUR A FAN OF LINDA BLAIR LIKE I AM, THIS IS A MUST SEE FILM. OR IF YOU JUST LIKE HORSES.

reviewText: Linda Blair is fantasic in this movie for all animal lovers to see, It keeps you interested all the way through, A great family show and the music is great as well, Richard Crenna acts the father role that suits him to a tee. Horses must be taken over the border to Canada and its wonderful to watch. A wonderful classic movie.
